metadata.title: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson  Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Inferior pole of patella and patellar tendon
description: Variation of patellar tendonitis, disturbance of patellar tendon attachment to inferior pole of the patella

ICD-10 codes.M92.4: juvenile osteochondrosis of patella (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference only, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients typically are athletic boys aged 10–13  years(3,5)
Localized aching pain and discomfort in the anterior knee, with tenderness at the inferior pole of patella(3,5)
Symptoms are usually aggravated by stair climbing, squatting, kneeling, jumping, and running.(3) A slight limp might even be observable(7)
Symptoms might be unilateral or bilateral, and intensity can vary from mild to acute(7) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: If major trauma or a single memorable event precedes anterior knee symptoms, a patellar sleeve fracture (i.e., cartilaginous avulsion fracture at the inferior pole of the patella) should be ruled out(6)

risk factors: More prevalent in young athletes, especially boys aged 10–13 years(3,5)
Children with spastic cerebral palsy are at increased risk for SLJS

overall contraindications precautions: Local corticosteroid injection is contraindicated due to potential for tendon weakness and rupture(3)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

contraindications precautions to examina: If major trauma or a single memorable event precedes anterior knee symptoms, a patellar sleeve fracture (i.e., cartilaginous avulsion fracture at the inferior pole of the patella) should be ruled out(6)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -A typical history involves the gradual onset of intermittent exertional knee pain, possibly during a growth spurt. If pain started suddenly, was trauma the cause? Have symptoms worsened with continued physical activity?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management for knee pain. How has the pain responded to treatments?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? NSAIDs are often recommended
diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis is usually made clinically
The presence of abnormalities on radiograph does not always correlate with patient symptoms(5)
Ultrasonography reliably tracks the course of SLJS and is indicated to rule out bone pathology if conservative treatment does not reduce the pain(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Anterior knee pain aggravated by using stairs, squatting, kneeling, jumping, and running
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Patients might point to the distal end of the patella as the source of anterior knee pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Aching discomfort localized at the inferior pole of the patella
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician. Although rare, pain around the knee joint can also occur with osteosarcoma,(3)which may present with symptoms such as weight loss, pallor, fever, and anorexia Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any previous skeletal problems or injury to the involved knee?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders. Review health history questionnaire with the patient
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What sports or recreational activities are involved?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document use of any assistive or adaptive devices, as well as any functional limitations such as stair climbing or kneeling during household duties
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc.

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height and weight. Quadriceps atrophy might be assessed by taking muscle girth measurements
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assessment indicated in severe cases that might require crutch use
relevant tests and measures.balance: Should be normal if the knees are fully extended. However, if pain and swelling are extensive, balance might be impaired
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Peripheral pulses should be normal Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.) –Assess ability to use stairs, kneel, or squat –If an athlete or highly active patient has difficulty reproducing his or her symptoms, assess ability to perform sports-related  motion that increases his or her pain
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait pattern. A patient with severe SLJS might have an antalgic gait pattern or excessive compensatory mechanismsKnee joint mechanics should be normal. Assess for patellar hypomobility, patella infera, or patella alta.(3)Assess hip for abnormalities to rule out referred pain(5)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess knee strength in extension and flexion. Quadriceps weakness and atrophy might be present in severe cases. Pain on resisted knee extension is very common
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess leg alignment and check for leg-length discrepancy. Check for factors that might increase stress on patellar tendon, such as genu recurvatum
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess for loss of full active knee extension, which might be indicative of an avulsion fracture. Passive knee extension should be normal unless knee effusion exists. Assess for pain-restricted  passive knee flexion ROM in prone (Ely’s test) to determine if the cause of any discovered restrictions is hip flexor or quadriceps tightness. Also evaluate the flexibility of the hamstrings, gastrocnemius/soleus, and iliotibial band. Hip and ankle motion should be evaluated to determine if any restrictions exist that might be contributing to faulty biomechanics
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Patellar and Achilles deep tendon reflexes should be intactSLJS rarely causes disability in self-care  activities
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Ely’s test -Assess for restricted rectus femoris pain, restricted knee flexion ROM in prone -The test is positive if the hip rises from the table as the knee is flexed. If pain is elicited at the location of the patellar tendon or inferior pole of the patella instead of the typical stretch sensation in the muscle belly, then quadriceps stretching might need to be delayed –Ober’s test -Assess for tightness of iliotibial band and tensor fascia lata in side-lying -The test is positive if the lower extremity does not adduct to parallel

contraindications precautions: Raynaud’s syndrome
Over area of circulatory compromise
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Cold intolerance
Cryoglobulinemia
Cold urticaria
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria
Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves
Hypertension
Thermoregulatory disorders
Over a superficial peripheral nerve
Over an open wound
Over an area of poor sensation
With individuals with poor cognition
In the very young or very old
Persons with aversion to cold
Application over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Application over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Application over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Application over areas of known malignancy
Application over areas of acute inflammation
Application over infected areas where infection may spread or cross-contamination  may occur
Application over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
Application in any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner

Electrodes should not be placed over -the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators -the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region in pregnant women -the carotid bodies -the phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators -areas of known peripheral vascular disease including arterial or venous thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -areas of active osteomyelitis -areas of hemorrhage

Electrotherapy should be used with caution -in patients without intact sensation -in patients who are unable to communicate -in patients with compromised mental status -in patients with cardiac dysfunction -in patients with epilepsy
Electrodes should not be placed -over neoplasms -over compromised skin -over tissues vulnerable to hemorrhage or hematoma -over the cervical or craniofacial region
other: Electrotherapy contraindications  (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(2)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Activity-related  knee pain. Guided intervention needed for activity modification and pain management
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Referred pain from hip/hip pathology Patellar sleeve fracture(3) Patellar stress fracture(3) Patellar tendinitis(3)  Patella alta(3) Patella infera Osteochondritis dissecans(3) Malignancy(8) Infection(8) Type I bipartite patella(4) Patellofemoral syndrome Chondromalacia
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: As indicated if another medical condition is suspected, such as tumor or infection

maintenance or prevention: Maintain appropriate flexibility and strength of quadriceps and hamstrings for sport or activities
